<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The abilities of two readily available tartaric acid derivatives to bind Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> have been evaluated using NMR Job plots and titrations. Dimethyl tartrate exhibits 1:1 binding while dipyrrolidine tartramide exhibits 2:1 binding. In contrast, the crystal structure of the dipyrrolidine tartramide complex of NaI shows a 1:1 binding stoichiometry.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

The abilities of two readily available tartaric acid derivatives to bind Na+ have been evaluated using NMR Job plots and titrations. Dimethyl tartrate exhibits 1:1 binding while dipyrrolidine tartramide exhibits 2:1 binding. In contrast, the crystal structure of the dipyrrolidine tartramide complex of NaI shows a 1:1 binding stoichiometry.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">A study of the binding of Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> by two readily available tartaric acid derivatives, dimethyl tartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide, has been carried out. These binding studies reveal binding stoichiometries of 1:1 for the dimethyl tartrate and 2:1 for the dipyrrolidine tartramide, and binding affinities (association constants) of 6.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the dimethyl tartrate and 70.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup> for the dipyrrolidine tartramide indicating weak binding of Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> in both cases. An X-ray crystal structure of a NaI complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide has also been determined. The binding stoichiometry is 1:1 in the solid state as opposed to the 2:1 binding stoichiometry that is observed in solution. The 1:1 binding in the solid state results in a coordination polymer in which half of the carbonyl oxygens and half of the hydroxy oxygens of the dipyrrolidine tartramide ligand bridge between adjacent Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cations. This allows each Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation to achieve an octahedral coordination geometry. The iodides are ordered in a linear fashion, and each column of iodides is separated from the other columns by the coordination polymer and by linear columns of water molecules.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A study of the binding of Na+ by two readily available tartaric acid derivatives, dimethyl tartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide, has been carried out. These binding studies reveal binding stoichiometries of 1:1 for the dimethyl tartrate and 2:1 for the dipyrrolidine tartramide, and binding affinities (association constants) of 6.61M-1 for the dimethyl tartrate and 70.4M-2 for the dipyrrolidine tartramide indicating weak binding of Na+ in both cases. An X-ray crystal structure of a NaI complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide has also been determined. The binding stoichiometry is 1:1 in the solid state as opposed to the 2:1 binding stoichiometry that is observed in solution. The 1:1 binding in the solid state results in a coordination polymer in which half of the carbonyl oxygens and half of the hydroxy oxygens of the dipyrrolidine tartramide ligand bridge between adjacent Na+ cations. This allows each Na+ cation to achieve an octahedral coordination geometry. The iodides are ordered in a linear fashion, and each column of iodides is separated from the other columns by the coordination polymer and by linear columns of water molecules.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Recently we reported that the addition of hard metal cations to styrene hydroformylation reactions catalyzed by Rh(I) complexes of the bis(phosphite) ligands caused a significant increase in the regioselectivity (an approximately three fold increase in the <ce:italic>iso</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> ratio was observed with a 32:1 ratio of LiBPh<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> to Rh when the bis(phosphite) ligand was (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>)-Chiraphite<ce:sup loc="post">®</ce:sup>
. This increase was attributed to cation binding to phosphite ligands during the regioselectivity determining step.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Recently we reported that the addition of hard metal cations to styrene hydroformylation reactions catalyzed by Rh(I) complexes of the bis(phosphite) ligands caused a significant increase in the regioselectivity (an approximately three fold increase in the iso/n ratio was observed with a 32:1 ratio of LiBPh4 to Rh when the bis(phosphite) ligand was (R,R)-Chiraphite® . This increase was attributed to cation binding to phosphite ligands during the regioselectivity determining step.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Our catalytic results suggest that the incorporation of groups that are capable of binding hard metal cations may have interesting effects on the regioselectivities of hydroformylation catalysts. Because a number of bis(phosphorus-donor) ligands used in hydroformylation catalysts are derived from tartaric acid , cation binding by tartaric acid derivatives is of interest. Unfortunately, there are no studies of the alkali metal binding by tartrate esters or tartramides so it is impossible to predict, <ce:italic>a priori</ce:italic>, if hard metal cation binding to these tartaric acid derivatives will occur.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Our catalytic results suggest that the incorporation of groups that are capable of binding hard metal cations may have interesting effects on the regioselectivities of hydroformylation catalysts. Because a number of bis(phosphorus-donor) ligands used in hydroformylation catalysts are derived from tartaric acid , cation binding by tartaric acid derivatives is of interest. Unfortunately, there are no studies of the alkali metal binding by tartrate esters or tartramides so it is impossible to predict, a priori, if hard metal cation binding to these tartaric acid derivatives will occur.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">To remedy this deficiency, we have studied the ability of dimethyltartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) to bind sodium cations. The binding stoichiometries were determined using Job plots and binding affinities were determined by fitting NMR titration data to the appropriate model. An X-ray crystal structure of a NaI complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide has also been determined, and the insights that it provides into the binding of NaI by these molecules are discussed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To remedy this deficiency, we have studied the ability of dimethyltartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide (1) to bind sodium cations. The binding stoichiometries were determined using Job plots and binding affinities were determined by fitting NMR titration data to the appropriate model. An X-ray crystal structure of a NaI complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide has also been determined, and the insights that it provides into the binding of NaI by these molecules are discussed.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General considerations

NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DRX400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts for 1H and 13C data are reported in ppm downfield from internal tetramethylsilane (TMS) using residual protons (or carbons) in the acetonitrile-d 3 (1.94ppm for 1H and 118.69ppm and 1.39ppm for 13C). Acetonitrile-d 3 was obtained from Cambridge Isotope Laboratories and used as received. THF was obtained from Aldrich and distilled from Na/benzophenone prior to use. Dimethyl tartrate and NaI were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. The dipyrrolidine tartramide (1) was synthesized using a known literature procedure .

Then the reaction mixture was stirred overnight during which time a white solid precipitated from the solution. The precipitate collected by filtration and dried <ce:italic>in vacuo</ce:italic>. Recrystallization from acetone/ethyl acetate yielded 0.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (90%) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NaI<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O as colorless prisms. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR (CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 4.56 (d, 2H, |<ce:sup loc="pre">3</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(HH)| 7.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz, CH), 4.34 (d, 2H, |<ce:sup loc="pre">3</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>(HH)| 8.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Hz, OH), 3.61 (m, 2H, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N), 3.46 (m, 6H, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N), 2.21 (s, 2H, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O), 1.92 (m, 8H, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C). <ce:sup loc="pre">13</ce:sup>C NMR (CD<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 170.31 (s, C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O), 69.97 (s, CH), 47.65 (s, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N), 47.27 (s, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N), 26.85 (s, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C), 24.46 (s, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">21</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NaI: C, 33.98; H, 5.23. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of dipyrrolidine tartramide-NaI complex (2)

A solution of 1.0g (4.0mmol) of dipyrrolidine tartramide (1) in 8.0mL of THF and was stirred as 0.6g (4mmol) of NaI was added. Then the reaction mixture was stirred overnight during which time a white solid precipitated from the solution. The precipitate collected by filtration and dried in vacuo. Recrystallization from acetone/ethyl acetate yielded 0.9g (90%) of 1 ⋅NaI⋅H2O as colorless prisms. 1H NMR (CD3CN): δ 4.56 (d, 2H, |3 J(HH)| 7.5Hz, CH), 4.34 (d, 2H, |3 J(HH)| 8.4Hz, OH), 3.61 (m, 2H, CH2N), 3.46 (m, 6H, CH2N), 2.21 (s, 2H, H2O), 1.92 (m, 8H, CH2C). 13C NMR (CD3CN): δ 170.31 (s, CO), 69.97 (s, CH), 47.65 (s, CH2N), 47.27 (s, CH2N), 26.85 (s, CH2C), 24.46 (s, CH2C). Anal. Calc. for C12H21O5N2NaI: C, 33.98; H, 5.23. Found: C, 34.22; H, 5.23%.

elements.clean_text:
Procedure for the determination of binding stoichiometry using a Job plot

A 0.50M stock solution of NaI in acetonitrile-d 3 (0.150g of NaI in 2.0mL) and a 0.50M stock solution of either dimethyl tartrate in acetonitrile-d 3 (0.178g of dimethyl tartrate in 2.0mL) or the dipyrrolidine tartramide in acetonitrile-d 3 (0.256g of tartramide in 2.0mL) were prepared. These stock solutions were then used to prepare ten solutions in NMR tubes with varying ratios of the tartrate derivative to the NaI. In each case, the total concentration of the sample remained constant. A 13C NMR spectrum of each solution was then taken, and the chemical shifts of the methyne carbons (13C δ: 70.30ppm for tartrate and 70.75ppm for tartramide), which were sensitive to cation binding, were measured. The resulting data was then plotted as the change in chemical shift (Δδ) times the concentration of tartrate or tartramide versus the mole fraction (χ) of NaI. The binding stoichiometry was determined by the point at which the curve reached a maximum.

The solution of tartaric acid derivative was placed in an NMR tube and then portions of the NaI solution were added using a 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL Hamilton syringe. elements.clean_text:
Procedure for the determination of binding constants by NMR titrations of dimethyl tartrate or dipyrrolidine tartramide with NaI

For each titration, a 0.50M stock solutions of NaI in acetonitrile-d 3 (0.150g in 2.0mL) and a 0.050M stock solution of the tartaric acid derivative in acetonitrile-d 3 (0.0045g of dimethyl tartrate in 0.50mL or 0.0064g dipyrrolidine tartramide in 0.5mL) were prepared. Both stock solutions were completely clear. The solution of tartaric acid derivative was placed in an NMR tube and then portions of the NaI solution were added using a 5μL Hamilton syringe. A 13C NMR spectrum was run after each aliquot was added. The addition was continued until almost no change 13C in the 13C NMR chemical shift of the methyne carbons (13C δ: 70.30ppm for dimethyl tartrate and 70.75ppm for dipyrrolidine tartramide) was observed. The data was then plotted as the change in chemical shift (Δδ) versus the NaI concentration. The binding constants were determined by fitting the plots to either a 1:1 or 2:1 literature binding models  that were modified for our experiments (see ).

<ce:section-title>X-ray data collection and solution</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A suitable single crystal of the compound was glued on a glass fiber with epoxy and aligned upon an Enraf Nonius CAD4 single crystal diffractometer under aerobic conditions. Standard peak search and automatic indexing routines followed by least-squares fits of 25 accurately centered reflections resulted in accurate unit cell parameters for each. The space group of the crystal was assigned on the basis of systematic absences and intensity statistics. The data collection was carried out using the <ce:small-caps>cad4-pc</ce:small-caps> software , and details of the data collection are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. The analytical scattering factors of the complex were corrected for both <ce:italic>Δf</ce:italic>′ and <ce:italic>iΔf</ce:italic>′′ components of anomalous dispersion. The data was corrected for the effects of absorption and for Lorentz and polarization effects.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray data collection and solution

A suitable single crystal of the compound was glued on a glass fiber with epoxy and aligned upon an Enraf Nonius CAD4 single crystal diffractometer under aerobic conditions. Standard peak search and automatic indexing routines followed by least-squares fits of 25 accurately centered reflections resulted in accurate unit cell parameters for each. The space group of the crystal was assigned on the basis of systematic absences and intensity statistics. The data collection was carried out using the cad4-pc software , and details of the data collection are given in  . The analytical scattering factors of the complex were corrected for both Δf' and iΔf'' components of anomalous dispersion. The data was corrected for the effects of absorption and for Lorentz and polarization effects.

<ce:para view="all">All crystallographic calculations were performed with the Siemens <ce:small-caps>shelxtl-pc</ce:small-caps> program package . All heavy atom positions were located using Direct Methods. Full matrix refinement of the positional and anisotropic thermal parameters for all these atoms versus <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> was carried out. All hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions with the appropriate molecular geometry and with a <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>(C–H) of 0.97<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for methylenes and of 0.98<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for methynes. The isotropic thermal parameter associated with each hydrogen atom was fixed equal to 1.2 times the U<ce:inf loc="post">eq</ce:inf> of the atom to which it was bound. Crystallographic data for the complex has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Database (<ce:bold>Na Complex w/1</ce:bold>: 692427).</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Binding studies

Both the dimethyl tartrate and the dipyrrolidine tartramide are readily available compounds, making them ideal for the binding studies presented herein. Dimethyl tartrate can be purchased inexpensively, while the dipyrrolidine tartramide can be synthesized easily from diethyltartrate and 2equiv of pyrrolidine in MeOH . Both compounds bind Na+ in acetonitrile-d 3 as demonstrated by changes in their 13C NMR spectra upon addition of NaI. The methyne resonances of both compounds are most sensitive to binding and were used in the Job plots and the NMR titrations.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Job plots for the binding of Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> to dimethyl tartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>. The Job plot for the binding of the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> by dimethyl tartrate indicates that the binding stoichiometry is 1:1. This is somewhat surprising in view of the small number of donor atoms on the dimethyl tartrate. In contrast, the Job plot for the binding of Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> by dipyrrolidene tartramide indicates that two molecules of the dipyrrolidene tartramide are needed to form a complex with Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>. This difference in binding stoichiometry suggests that the lone pairs on the methoxy oxygens in dimethyl tartramide may be involved the binding to Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> in order to form a stable six coordinate complex. The dipyrrolidene tartramide, which does not have these donor groups and also is more sterically hindered, would need additional donor atoms from an adjacent molecule to form an octahedral coordination geometry around the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Job plots for the binding of Na+ to dimethyl tartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide are shown in   . The Job plot for the binding of the Na+ by dimethyl tartrate indicates that the binding stoichiometry is 1:1. This is somewhat surprising in view of the small number of donor atoms on the dimethyl tartrate. In contrast, the Job plot for the binding of Na+ by dipyrrolidene tartramide indicates that two molecules of the dipyrrolidene tartramide are needed to form a complex with Na+. This difference in binding stoichiometry suggests that the lone pairs on the methoxy oxygens in dimethyl tartramide may be involved the binding to Na+ in order to form a stable six coordinate complex. The dipyrrolidene tartramide, which does not have these donor groups and also is more sterically hindered, would need additional donor atoms from an adjacent molecule to form an octahedral coordination geometry around the Na+.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">To gain some insight into the strength of the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> binding by dimethyl tartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide, the titrations of these molecules with NaI have been followed by <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR spectroscopy. The titration curves, shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, are consistent with the formation of a 1:1 complex of dimethyl tartrate and Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> and of a 2:1 complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide and Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>. The fact that there is no evidence of an intermediate 1:1 binding stoichiometry with dipyrrolidine tartramide and NaI further supports the suggestion that the dipyrrolidine tartramide does not have sufficient binding sites to form a stable 1:1 complex with Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> in solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: To gain some insight into the strength of the Na+ binding by dimethyl tartrate and dipyrrolidine tartramide, the titrations of these molecules with NaI have been followed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. The titration curves, shown in   , are consistent with the formation of a 1:1 complex of dimethyl tartrate and Na+ and of a 2:1 complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide and Na+. The fact that there is no evidence of an intermediate 1:1 binding stoichiometry with dipyrrolidine tartramide and NaI further supports the suggestion that the dipyrrolidine tartramide does not have sufficient binding sites to form a stable 1:1 complex with Na+ in solution.

The <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>

<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> stability constant derived from the 2:1 fit of the dipyrrolidine tartramide titration is 70.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>. The stability constants are not directly comparable because of the different binding stoichiometries, but both binding constants are consistent with the weak binding suggested by the shapes of both the Job plots and titration curves.</ce:para>

The 1:1 and 2:1 fits were verified by comparison of the calculated NMR chemical shift of the methyne carbon in the completely bound species with that measured in a solution with high ratios of NaI to dimethyl tartrate or dipyrrolidine tartramide. The K c stability constant derived from the 1:1 fit of the dimethyl tartrate titration with NaI is 6.61M-1, and K c stability constant derived from the 2:1 fit of the dipyrrolidine tartramide titration is 70.37M-2. The stability constants are not directly comparable because of the different binding stoichiometries, but both binding constants are consistent with the weak binding suggested by the shapes of both the Job plots and titration curves.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> binding by the tartrate derivates described above is significantly weaker than Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> binding to crown ether derivatives. Sessler and coworkers  have reported stability constants for Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> with crowned dipyrrolylquinoxalines ranging from 200 to 57500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Watt and coworkers  have reported stability constants for Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> with crown ethers containing 4,5-dioxyxanthone backbones with Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ranging from >200 to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. In both cases, the lowest of these stability constants with crown ethers was roughly 35 times higher than that with dimethyl tartrate.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The Na+ binding by the tartrate derivates described above is significantly weaker than Na+ binding to crown ether derivatives. Sessler and coworkers  have reported stability constants for Na+ with crowned dipyrrolylquinoxalines ranging from 200 to 57500M-1. Watt and coworkers  have reported stability constants for Na+ with crown ethers containing 4,5-dioxyxanthone backbones with Na+ ranging from >200 to 800M-1. In both cases, the lowest of these stability constants with crown ethers was roughly 35 times higher than that with dimethyl tartrate.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystal structure of the1:1 complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide and NaI</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">An X-ray quality single crystal of a dipyrrolidine tartramide complex of NaI was obtained by the slow evaporation of an ethyl acetate:acetone solution containing a 2:1 ratio of dipyrrolidine tartramide to NaI. Surprisingly, the crystal structure shows a 1:1 binding stoichiometry in contrast to the Job plot and titration studies in which a 2:1 stoichiometry is observed. The difference appears to be due to the fact that, in the solid state, half of the carbonyl and hydroxy oxygens bridge two of the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions allowing the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions to achieve the desired octahedral coordination geometry with a 1:1 binding stoichiometry. This bridging would be unlikely to occur in solution, thus requiring a 2:1 stoichiometry. There is no evidence of any coordination of the pyrrolidene nitrogens to the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions. As seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>, the bridging of the Na<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ions by the carbonyl and hydroxy oxygens of the dipyrrolidine tartramide results in the formation of a one dimensional coordination polymer. The iodides are ordered in a linear fashion, and each column of iodides is separated from the other columns by the coordination polymer and by linear columns of water molecules. The source of the water in the crystal is the acetone co-solvent used in the crystallization.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure of the1:1 complex of dipyrrolidine tartramide and NaI

An X-ray quality single crystal of a dipyrrolidine tartramide complex of NaI was obtained by the slow evaporation of an ethyl acetate:acetone solution containing a 2:1 ratio of dipyrrolidine tartramide to NaI. Surprisingly, the crystal structure shows a 1:1 binding stoichiometry in contrast to the Job plot and titration studies in which a 2:1 stoichiometry is observed. The difference appears to be due to the fact that, in the solid state, half of the carbonyl and hydroxy oxygens bridge two of the Na+ ions allowing the Na+ ions to achieve the desired octahedral coordination geometry with a 1:1 binding stoichiometry. This bridging would be unlikely to occur in solution, thus requiring a 2:1 stoichiometry. There is no evidence of any coordination of the pyrrolidene nitrogens to the Na+ ions. As seen in   , the bridging of the Na+ ions by the carbonyl and hydroxy oxygens of the dipyrrolidine tartramide results in the formation of a one dimensional coordination polymer. The iodides are ordered in a linear fashion, and each column of iodides is separated from the other columns by the coordination polymer and by linear columns of water molecules. The source of the water in the crystal is the acetone co-solvent used in the crystallization.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Tartaric acid derivatives are weak binders of sodium cations. The types and number of donor atoms greatly affects the stoichiometry of the complex observed. In addition, these stoichiometries can be very different in solution than in the solid state. Future work in this area will focus on the additional derivatives which can be synthesized containing phosphorous-donor ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Tartaric acid derivatives are weak binders of sodium cations. The types and number of donor atoms greatly affects the stoichiometry of the complex observed. In addition, these stoichiometries can be very different in solution than in the solid state. Future work in this area will focus on the additional derivatives which can be synthesized containing phosphorous-donor ligands.

The <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> stability constant derived from the 1:1 fit of the dimethyl tartrate titration with NaI is 6.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf> stability constant derived from the 2:1 fit of the dipyrrolidine tartramide titration is 70.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M<ce:sup loc="post">−2</ce:sup>. The stability constants are not directly comparable because of the different binding stoichiometries, but both binding constants are consistent with the weak binding suggested by the shapes of both the Job plots and titration curves.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Each titration curve was easily fit to the appropriate binding stoichiometry models but all attempts at fitting the titration curves to different binding stoichiometry models were unsuccessful. The 1:1 and 2:1 fits were verified by comparison of the calculated NMR chemical shift of the methyne carbon in the completely bound species with that measured in a solution with high ratios of NaI to dimethyl tartrate or dipyrrolidine tartramide. The K c stability constant derived from the 1:1 fit of the dimethyl tartrate titration with NaI is 6.61M-1, and K c stability constant derived from the 2:1 fit of the dipyrrolidine tartramide titration is 70.37M-2. The stability constants are not directly comparable because of the different binding stoichiometries, but both binding constants are consistent with the weak binding suggested by the shapes of both the Job plots and titration curves.

etc.condition: 1:1 fit of dimethyl tartrate titration with NaI
